text:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion,

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it is not selfish to participate in an extreme sport. People have their reasons for participating in sports like these and i dont think anyone should be limited as to what they can and can not do. It is simply their own decision. I know i personally have participated in violent sports all my life. I played football from the time i was a kid through graduating in college, and I am now doing boxing. To me, it is therapeutic to participate in sports like these because they challenge my mind and my athleticism. Working out to become better athlete is something that has always given me a goal, and something to drive for. In addition to that, i like to push myself and realize that if i can push myself in exercise, then i can anytime i am having a difficult time in life. I would guess that many people who do extreme sports are adrenaline junkies in a way, and need this sort of action in their life as they cant get it from every day tasks. This in turn calms their mind and allows them to have something to look forward to that quenches their adrenaline. I just think that everyone has a purpose for what they do, and it is not someone else to tell them what they can and can not do. Of course there are situations where the action can be looked at as selfish, but to them it may not me. There could be a dad who has four kids, but still does mountain climbing. Maybe he wants to be a role model to the kids and show them how to face their fears. Or maybe he simply wants to calm his mind so he can be present, and be a good father. Not everyone does it for these good and genuine reasons, but who are we to pick and choose?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

People have their reasons for participating in sports like these and i dont think anyone should be limited as to what they can and can not do. It is simply their own decision. In addition to that, i like to push myself and realize that if i can push myself in exercise, then i can anytime i am having a difficult time in life. I would guess that many people who do extreme sports are adrenaline junkies in a way, and need this sort of action in their life as they cant get it from every day tasks. Of course there are situations where the action can be looked at as selfish, but to them it may not me. There could be a dad who has four kids, but still does mountain climbing. Maybe he wants to be a role model to the kids and show them how to face their fears. Or maybe he simply wants to calm his mind so he can be present, and be a good father. Not everyone does it for these good and genuine reasons, but who are we to pick and choose? If its bad choice in your opinion, then no one is making you watch the action. 

So as far as drawing a line, i would simply say that the person themselves should draw it. People make bad decisions everyday doing things they should not do, thats part of life. I think it can be selfish to pursue things like risky sports, but it depends on perspective. From the outside in it may seem selfish, but to them it may not. Sometimes it truly may be selfish to them as well, but we simply are not in their shoes and dont really have the right to dictate that in my opinion.

I think it can be selfish to pursue things like risky sports, but it depends on perspective. From the outside in it may seem selfish, but to them it may not. Sometimes it truly may be selfish to them as well, but we simply are not in their shoes and dont really have the right to dictate that in my opinion. I think that once you start telling people they cant do what they want to, or limiting their right to choose, then you are taking away their heart in a way. Just think of the situation today. People are literally not doing things they know would be smart, simply because they dont want to be told what to do. Wearing masks for example. Yea it may be difficult for some people, but i would assume most people would agree that if it has any impact on lessening chances of gaining COVID, why not wear them, at least for our senior citizens. Shoot, ill wear a mascot costume if i am going to save people's lives.

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. I think it can be selfish to pursue things like risky sports, but it depends on perspective. From the outside in it may seem selfish, but to them it may not. Sometimes it truly may be selfish to them as well, but we simply are not in their shoes and dont really have the right to dictate that in my opinion. I think that once you start telling people they cant do what they want to, or limiting their right to choose, then you are taking away their heart in a way. Just think of the situation today. Yea it may be difficult for some people, but i would assume most people would agree that if it has any impact on lessening chances of gaining COVID, why not wear them, at least for our senior citizens.
